doc.text: A UGen that reports the server's current control rate. This is equivalent to the reciprocal of `ControlDur`
A UGen that reports the server's current (audio) sample rate. This is equivalent to the reciprocal of `SampleDur`
A UGen that reports the server's current (audio) sample period in seconds. This is equivalent to the reciprocal of `SampleRate`
A UGen that reports the server's current control period in seconds. This is equivalent to the reciprocal of `ControlRate`

A UGen that reports the fractional sample offset of the current Synth from its requested scheduled start.
When a synth is created from a time stamped osc-bundle, it starts calculation at the next possible block (normally 64 samples). Using an `OffsetOut` UGen, one can delay the audio so that it matches sample accurately.
For some synthesis methods, one even needs subsample accuracy. `SubsampleOffset` provides the information where, within the current sample, the synth was scheduled. It can be used to offset envelopes or resample the audio output.

A UGen that delivers the conversion factor from frequency in Hertz to radians (normalized frequency). The relation is `RadiansPerSample * sr = 2pi`, thus multiplying the UGen with a frequency between zero and nyquist (sr/2) yields the normalized frequency between zero and pi.
Number of input busses.
Number of output busses.
Number of audio busses.
Number of control busses.
Number of open buffers.
Number of currently running synths.
Returns the buffer's current sample rate.
Returns the buffer's current sample rate.

arg.name: buf
arg.doc: Buffer index.

arg.name: numChannels
arg.doc: the number of channels that the buffer will be. Since this is a constant, a change in number of channels of the underlying bus must be reflected by creating different SynthDefs. If a buffer identifier is used of a buffer that has a different numChannels then specified in the PlayBuf, it will fail silently.

arg.name: buf
arg.doc: the identifier of the buffer to use

arg.name: speed
arg.doc: 1.0 advances the play head by the server's sample rate each second, so 2.0 means doubling speed (and pitch), and 0.5 means half speed (and half pitch). Negative numbers can be used for backwards playback. If the underlying buffer represents a sound at a different sample rate, the rate should be multiplied by `BufRateScale.kr( bufID )` to obtain the correct speed.

arg.name: trig
arg.doc: a trigger which causes a jump to the given startPos. A trigger occurs when a signal changes from non-positive to positive (e.g. <= 0 to > 0).

arg.name: startPos
arg.doc: sample frame to start playback. This is read when a trigger occurs.

arg.name: loop
arg.doc: 1 to loop after the play head reaches the buffer end, 0 to not loop. this can be modulated.

arg.name: doneAction
arg.doc: what to do when the play head reaches the buffer end.

doc.text:
A UGen to play back samples from a buffer in memory.
`PlayBuf` provides a kind of high-level interface to sample-playback, whereas `BufRd` represents a kind of lower-level access. While `BufRd` has a random-access-pointer in the form of a phase input, `PlayBuf` advances the phase automatically based on a given playback speed. `PlayBuf` uses cubic interpolation.

Records input into a Buffer. If recLevel is 1.0 and preLevel is 0.0 then the new input overwrites the old data. If they are both 1.0 then the new data is added to the existing data. (Any other settings are also valid.)

Records input into a Buffer. If recLevel is 1.0 and preLevel is 0.0 then the new input overwrites the old data. If they are both 1.0 then the new data is added to the existing data. (Any other settings are also valid.)

arg.name: numChannels
arg.doc: number of channels that the buffer will be. Since this is an integer constant, a change in the number of channels must be reflected by creating different SynthDefs.

arg.name: buf
arg.doc: the identifier of the buffer to use

arg.name: index
arg.doc: audio rate frame-index into the buffer.

arg.name: loop
arg.doc: 1 to enable looping, 0 to disable looping. this can be modulated.

arg.name: interp
arg.doc: 1 for no interpolation, 2 for linear, and 4 for cubic interpolation

doc.text:
A UGen which reads the content of a buffer, using an index pointer.
Warning: if the supplied `bufID` refers to a buffer whose number of channels differs from `numChannels`, the UGen will fail silently.
An alternative to `BufRd` is `PlayBuf`. While `PlayBuf` plays through the buffer by itself, `BufRd` only moves its read point by the phase input and therefore has no pitch input. `PlayBuf` uses cubic interplation, while `BufRd` has variable interpolation. `PlayBuf` can determine the end of the buffer and issue a done-action.

arg.name: in
arg.doc: The signal to be analyzed.

arg.name: initFreq
arg.doc: The initial value of the `freq` output, until the first valid pitch is found.

arg.name: minFreq
arg.doc: The minimum frequency in Hertz to be considered for reporting. (This parameter is scalar only?)

arg.name: maxFreq
arg.doc: The maximum frequency in Hertz to be considered for reporting. (This parameter is scalar only?)

arg.name: execFreq
arg.doc: The frequency at which the pitch is estimated. This will be automatically clipped to be between `minFreq` and `maxFreq`. This parameter is scalar only.

arg.name: binsPerOct
arg.doc: A value which guides the search for the peak frequency in the first coarse step. Its setting does *not* affect the final pitch resolution; setting it larger will cause the coarse search to take longer, and setting it smaller will cause the fine search to take longer. This parameter is scalar only.

arg.name: median
arg.doc: This specifies the length of a median filter applied to the frequency output estimation. With the default value of `1` the filter is defeated. Median filtering can help eliminating single spikes and jitter. This will however add latency to the output. This parameter is scalar only.

arg.name: ampThresh
arg.doc: The minimum amplitude threshold above which the pitch follower operates. An input signal below this threshold is not analyzed. (This parameter is scalar only?)

arg.name: peakThresh
arg.doc: This is a threshold used to find the first peak in the autocorrelation signal which gives the reported frequency. It is a factor of the energy of the signal (autocorrelation coefficient at zero). Set this value higher (e.g. to `1`) to eliminate false frequencies corresponding to overtones. (This parameter is scalar only?)

arg.name: downSample
arg.doc: An integer factor by which the input signal is down sampled to reduce CPU overhead. This will also reduce the pitch resolution. The default value of `1` means that the input signal is not down sampled. This parameter is scalar only.

arg.name: clarity
arg.doc: If the `clarity` argument is greater than zero (it is zero by default) then the `hasFreq` output is given additional detail. Rather than simply being 1 when a pitch is detected, it is a "clarity" measure in the range between zero and one. (Technically, it's the height of the autocorrelation peak normalised by the height of the zero-lag peak.) It therefore gives a kind of measure of "purity" of the pitched signal. This parameter is scalar only.

doc.text:
An autocorrelation based pitch following UGen. It is more accurate than `ZeroCrossing`, but more also more CPU costly. For most purposes the default settings can be used and only `in` needs to be supplied.
The UGen has two outputs: The first output is the frequency estimate in Hertz, the second output is a toggle `hasFreq`, which tells whether a pitch was found (1) or not (0). If the `clarify` argument is used, `hasFreq` has more fine grained information.
The pitch follower executes periodically at the rate specified by `execFreq` in cps. First it detects whether the input peak to peak amplitude is above the `ampThresh`. If it is not then no pitch estimation is performed, the `hasFreq` output is set to zero and the `freq` output is held at its previous value. Otherwise, the autocorrelation is calculated, and the first peak after the peak around the lag of zero that is above `peakThresh` times the amplitude of the peak at lag zero is reported.

arg.name: in
arg.doc: The input signal.

arg.name: winSize
arg.doc: The size of the grain window in seconds. This value cannot be modulated.

arg.name: pitchRatio
arg.doc: The ratio of the pitch shift. Must be from 0 to 4.

arg.name: pitchDispersion
arg.doc: The maximum random deviation of the pitch from the pitchRatio .

arg.name: timeDispersion
arg.doc: A random offset of from zero to timeDispersion seconds is added to the delay of each grain. Use of some dispersion can alleviate a hard comb filter effect due to uniform grain placement. It can also be an effect in itself. timeDispersion can be no larger than windowSize .

doc.text: A time domain granular pitch shifter. Grains have a triangular amplitude envelope and an overlap of 4:1.

arg.name: numChannels
arg.doc: Number of output channels.

arg.name: trig
arg.doc: At each trigger, the following arguments are sampled and used as the arguments of a new grain. A trigger occurs when a signal changes from non-positive to positive value. If the trigger is audio rate then the grains will start with sample accuracy.

arg.name: buf
arg.doc: The buffer index. It must be a one channel (mono) buffer.

arg.name: speed
arg.doc: 1.0 is normal, 2.0 is one octave up, 0.5 is one octave down -1.0 is backwards normal rate… etc.

arg.name: centerPos
arg.doc: The position in the buffer in seconds at which the grain envelope will reach maximum amplitude.

arg.name: dur
arg.doc: Duration of the grain in seconds.

arg.name: pan
arg.doc: A value from -1 to 1. Determines where to pan the output in the same manner as [[ugen.PanAz]].

arg.name: amp
arg.doc: Amplitude of the grain.

arg.name: interp
arg.doc: 1, 2, or 4. Determines whether the grain uses (1) no interpolation, (2) linear interpolation, or (4) cubic interpolation.

arg.name: in
arg.doc: An excitation signal.

arg.name: trig
arg.doc: Upon a negative to positive transition, the excitation signal will be fed into the delay line.

arg.name: maxDelayTime
arg.doc: Maximum delay time in seconds (initializes the internal delay buffer).

arg.name: delayTime
arg.doc: Delay time in seconds.

arg.name: decayTime
arg.doc: Time for the echoes to decay by 60 decibels. Negative times emphasize odd partials.

arg.name: coef
arg.doc: the coef of the internal OnePole filter. Values should be between -1 and +1 (larger values will be unstable... so be careful!).

doc.text: A Karplus-Strong UGen.

doc.text: Write to a buffer for a `DelTapRd` UGen

arg.name: buf
arg.doc: Buffer where DelTapWr has written signal. Max delay time is based on buffer size.

arg.name: phase
arg.doc: the current phase of the DelTapWr UGen. This is the output of DelTapWr.

arg.name: delayTime
arg.doc: Delay time in seconds.

arg.name: interp
arg.doc: The kind of interpolation to be used. 1 is none, 2 is linear, 4 is cubic..

doc.text: Tap a delay line from a `DelTapWr` UGen.

arg.name: trig
arg.doc: trigger. Can be any signal. A trigger happens when the signal changes from non-positive to positive.

arg.name: reset
arg.doc: trigger. Resets the list of ugens (`in`) when triggered.

arg.name: in
arg.doc: a demand-rate signal (possibly multi-channel) which is read at each trigger

doc.text:
A UGen which polls results from demand-rate ugens when receiving a trigger. When there is a trigger at the `trig` input, a value is demanded from each ugen in the `in` input and output. The unit generators in the list should be demand-rate. When there is a trigger at the reset input, the demand rate ugens in the list are reset.
Note: By design, a reset trigger only resets the demand ugens; it does not reset the value at Demand's output. Demand continues to hold its value until the next value is demanded, at which point its output value will be the first expected item in the `in` argument.
Note: One demand-rate ugen represents a single stream of values, so that embedding the same ugen twice calls this stream twice per demand, possibly yielding different values. To embed the same sequence twice, either make sure the ugen is demanded only once, or create two instances of the ugen.
'''Warning''': Demand currently seems to have problems with infinite sequences. As a workaround use a very large length instead. E.g. instead of `Dbrown( 0, 1, inf )` use `Dbrown( 0, 1, 0xFFFFFFFF )`!

arg.name: dur
arg.doc: the provider of time values. Can be a demand-rate ugen or any signal. The next poll is acquired after the previous duration.

arg.name: reset
arg.doc: a trigger which resets the dur input (if demand-rated) and the the level input ugen. The reset input may also be a demand-rate ugen, in this case providing a stream of reset times.

arg.name: level
arg.doc: a demand-rate ugen providing the output values.

arg.name: doneAction
arg.doc: a doneAction that is evaluated when the duration stream ends.

doc.text: A UGen which polls results from demand-rate ugens in intervals specified by a durational input. A value from the `level` ugen is demanded and output according to a stream of duration values. When there is a trigger at the reset input, the `level` and the `dur` input are reset.

arg.name: dur
arg.doc: the provider of time values. Can be a demand-rate ugen or any signal. The next poll is acquired after the previous duration.

arg.name: reset
arg.doc: a trigger which resets the dur input (if demand-rated) and the the level input ugen. The reset input may also be a demand-rate ugen, in this case providing a stream of reset times.

arg.name: level
arg.doc: a demand-rate ugen providing the output values.

arg.name: doneAction
arg.doc: a doneAction that is evaluated when the duration stream ends.

arg.name: gapFirst
arg.doc: when 0 (default), the UGen does the first level poll immediately and then waits for the first durational value. When this is 1, the UGen initially polls the first durational value, waits for that duration, and then polls the first level (along with polling the next durational value).

doc.text: A UGen which polls results from demand-rate ugens in intervals specified by a durational input, and outputs them as trigger values. A value from the `level` ugen is demanded and output for one sample (when running at audio-rate) or one block (when running at control-rate) according to a stream of duration values. When there is a trigger at the reset input, the `level` and the `dur` input are reset.

arg.name: levels
arg.doc: demand-rate ugen (or other ugen) returning level values

arg.name: durs
arg.doc: demand-rate ugen (or other ugen) returning durational values

arg.name: shapes
arg.doc: demand-rate ugen (or other ugen) returning shape number for the envelope segment.

arg.name: curvatures
arg.doc: demand-rate ugen (or other ugen) returning curvature values. these are used for curveShape segments (shape number 5) and should be zero for other shapes.

arg.name: gate
arg.doc: a control rate gate: if gate is x >= 1, the ugen runs. if gate is 0 > x > 1, the ugen is released at the next level (according to doneAction). if gate is x <= 0, the ugen is sampled end held.

arg.name: reset
arg.doc: a trigger signal. a trigger occurs when passing from non-positive to positive. when the trigger amplitude is < 1, the input ugens (those that are demand-rated) are reset when the current segment ends. if the trigger amplitude is > 1, the reset is performed immediately.

arg.name: levelScale
arg.doc: demand-rate ugen returning level scaling values

arg.name: levelBias
arg.doc: demand-rate ugen returning level offset values

arg.name: timeScale
arg.doc: demand-rate ugen returning time scaling values

arg.name: doneAction
arg.doc: a done action performed when one of the demand-rated series ends

doc.text: An envelope generator UGen using demand-rate inputs for the envelope segments. For each parameter of the envelope (levels, durations and shapes), values are polled every time a new segment starts.

arg.name: start
arg.doc: the start value of the series

arg.name: step
arg.doc: the incremental step by which the series changes. the step is added to the previous value on each demand.

arg.name: length
arg.doc: the number of elements to produces (maybe be infinite)

doc.text:
A demand-rate UGen which produces an arithmetic (linear) series.
The arguments can be constant or any other ugens.

arg.name: buf
arg.doc: the identifier of the buffer to read out

arg.name: index
arg.doc: the frame index into the buffer

arg.name: loop
arg.doc: whether to wrap an exceeding phase around the buffer length (1) or not (0)

doc.text: A demand-rate UGen that reads out a buffer. All inputs can be either demand ugen or any other ugen.

arg.name: in
arg.doc: the signal you want to poll

arg.name: run
arg.doc: if 1 the polling is active, if 0 it is inactive.

arg.name: label
arg.doc: a string or symbol to be printed with the polled value

doc.text: A demand rate UGen printing the current output value of its input to the console when polled.

arg.name: numChannels
arg.doc: the amount of channels the file and the buffer will have. This is an Int and hence must be pre-determined. Different SynthDefs must be created for different numbers of channels.

arg.name: buf
arg.doc: the id of the buffer with the correct number of channels and frames

arg.name: loop
arg.doc: whether the file should loop when its end is reached

doc.text:
A UGen to stream in a signal from an audio file. Continuously plays a longer audio file from disk. This requires a buffer to be preloaded with one buffer size of sound. If loop is set to 1, the file will loop.
'''Note''': The buffer size must be a multiple of (2 * the server's block size). See `Buffer#cue` for details.

arg.name: buf
arg.doc: the buffer used internally by the UGen. this number of frames in the buffer must be a power of two (this is currently not checked!). The buffer must have been initialized with a `write` command whose `leaveOpen` argument is true. Note that the number of channels of the buffer and of the input signal must be the same, otherwise `DiskOut` will fail silently (and not write anything to the file).

arg.name: in
arg.doc: the signal to be recorded

doc.text:
A UGen which writes a signal to a soundfile on disk. To achieve this efficiently, a buffer is needs to be provides which is used to buffer the incoming signal.
'''Note''': It might be that the buffer size must be a multiple of (2 * the server's block size). We haven't currently verified this, but to be safe, you should make sure this property is met.
The signal output by the UGen represents the number of frames written.

arg.name: numChannels
arg.doc: the amount of channels the file and the buffer will have. This is an Int and hence must be pre-determined. Different SynthDefs must be created for different numbers of channels

arg.name: buf
arg.doc: the id of the buffer with the correct number of channels and frames

arg.name: speed
arg.doc: controls the speed of playback. Values below 4 are probably fine, but the higher the value, the more disk activity there is, and the more likelihood there will be a problem. The following must be true: `rate < bufFrames / (2 * blockSize)`, e.g with typical default values, this will be `32768 / (2 * 64) = 256`.

arg.name: loop
arg.doc: whether the file should loop when its end is reached

arg.name: sendID
arg.doc: If a value other than zero is used, the UGen sends an OSC message with this id and the file position each time it reloads the buffer: `OSCMessage( "/diskin", nodeID, sendID, frame )`

doc.text:
A UGen to stream in a signal from an audio file with variable playback speed. Continuously plays a longer audio file from disk. This requires a buffer to be preloaded with one buffer size of sound. If loop is set to 1, the file will loop.
'''Note''': The buffer size must be a multiple of (2 * the server's block size). See `Buffer#cue` for details.
If the speed is too high, the UGen will not execute, posting a warning.

arg.name: freq
arg.doc: rate at which to generate random values.

doc.text:
A dynamic step noise UGen. Like `LFNoise0`, it generates abruptly changing random values between `-1` and `+1` at a rate given by the `freq` argument, with two differences: There is no time quantization, and it there is fast recovery from low freq values.
In contrast, `LFNoise0`, `LFNoise1`, and `LFNoise2` quantize to the nearest integer division of the samplerate, and they poll the freq argument only when scheduled, and thus seem to hang when freqs get very low.
If very high or very low freqs are not needed, or fixed freqs are used, `LFNoise0` is more efficient.

arg.name: freq
arg.doc: rate at which to generate random values.

doc.text:
A dynamic ramp noise UGen. Like `LFNoise1`, it generates linearly interpolated random values between `-1` and `+1` at a rate given by the `freq` argument, with two differences: There is no time quantization, and it there is fast recovery from low freq values.
In contrast, `LFNoise0`, `LFNoise1`, and `LFNoise2` quantize to the nearest integer division of the samplerate, and they poll the freq argument only when scheduled, and thus seem to hang when freqs get very low.
If very high or very low freqs are not needed, or fixed freqs are used, `LFNoise1` is more efficient.

arg.name: freq
arg.doc: rate at which to generate random values.

arg.name: freq
arg.doc: rate at which to generate random values.

ugen.name: FFT

arg.name: buf
arg.doc: The buffer to use for writing the FFT to. The size must be a power of two. Since `FFT` operates at control rate (also being a power of two), the buffer should probably be at least as long as the control block size.

arg.name: in
arg.doc: The time domain signal to be transformed into the spectral domain.

ugen.arg: A factor determining the step size between successive FFTs. That is, FFTs are performed every fftSize * hop sample frames. The default of 0.5 means thus a 50% overlap, while a hope of 1.0 means no overlapping. Choosing 0.0 will most likely crash the server!

arg.name: winType
arg.doc: The window function applied before each FFT is taken. The default of 0 is a sine window which is good for phase vocoder applications (using the `PV_...` UGens). For analysis applications, you may want to use -1 which is a rectangle window (effectively no windowing) or 1 which is a Hann window. A Hann window gives perfect overlap-add reconstruction for a hope size of 0.5 (or 0.25 etc.)

arg.name: active
arg.doc: This parameter can be temporarily set to <= 0 to pause the FFT operation.

arg.name: winSize
arg.doc: With the default value of zero, the window size equals the fft size. If you wish to perform zero padding, an explicit window size can be specified.

doc.text:
A UGen performing short-time forward fourier transformations. In order to properly link the spectral ugens (`PV_...`), you should begin by using the output of each UGen (which is just the fft buffer identifier), and use that as buffer input of the next UGen. That way, the UGen graph is correctly sorted. E.g. `IFFT( PV_...( FFT( buf, in )))`.
The UGen will initially output zero until the first FFT can be performed. This is the case after `hop * fftSize`. Thus for a default fft buffer size of 1024 and a `hop` of 0.5, and for a default control block size of 64, for the first 1024*0.5/64 = 8 control blocks the UGen will output zero. This also implies that the first FFT in this case if performed on the first 512 samples of the `in` signal (prepended by 512 zeros). In other words, the first 'full' FFT of the input happens after fftSize/controlBlockSize cycles, no matter what hop size was chosen.
If you use FFT for performing signal analysis and not phase vocoding effects, make sure you change the window type accordingly.

arg.name: buf
arg.doc: the identifier of the buffer to use

arg.name: hop
arg.doc: the hop size for timing triggers

arg.name: polar
arg.doc: whether the complex buffer content is given in cartesian coordinates (0) or in polar coordinates (1)

doc.text: A phase vocoder UGen that takes a buffer and prepares it to be used in FFT chains, without doing an actual FFT on a signal. This is useful if you want to provide a buffer whose content had already been transformed into the Fourier domain.

arg.name: chain
arg.doc: the FFT'ed buffer

arg.name: thresh
arg.doc: magnitude threshold.

doc.text: A phase vocoder UGen that passes only those bins whose magnitudes are above a given threshold.

arg.name: chain
arg.doc: the FFT'ed buffer

arg.name: thresh
arg.doc: magnitude threshold.

doc.text: A phase vocoder UGen that passes only those bins whose magnitudes are below a given threshold.

arg.name: chain
arg.doc: the FFT'ed buffer

arg.name: thresh
arg.doc: magnitude threshold. Each bin's magnitude is limited to be not greater than this threshold.

doc.text: A phase vocoder UGen that limits (clips) the magnitude of the bins to a given threshold.

arg.name: chainA
arg.doc: the first FFT'ed buffer (this gets replaced by the output signal)

arg.name: chainB
arg.doc: the second FFT'ed buffer

doc.text: A phase vocoder UGen that multiplies the magnitudes of two inputs and keeps the phases of the first input.

arg.name: chainA
arg.doc: the first FFT'ed buffer (this gets replaced by the output signal)

arg.name: chainB
arg.doc: the second FFT'ed buffer

arg.name: zeroes
arg.doc: the noise floor to assume when detecting zero bins in chainB that would cause a division by zero and hence blow up. The ugen will use divide by this magnitude instead when zeroes are detected, resulting in a maximum boost of `zeroes.reciprocal`.

doc.text: A phase vocoder UGen that divides magnitudes of two inputs and keeps the phases of the first input.

arg.name: chain
arg.doc: the FFT'ed buffer

doc.text: A phase vocoder UGen that squares the magnitudes and re-normalizes to previous peak. This makes weak bins weaker.

arg.name: chain
arg.doc: the FFT'ed buffer

doc.text: A phase vocoder UGen that multiplies the magnitudes by random noise.

arg.name: chainA
arg.doc: the first FFT'ed buffer (this gets replaced by the output signal)

arg.name: chainB
arg.doc: the second FFT'ed buffer

doc.text: A phase vocoder UGen that copies the spectral frames from chainA to chainB. This allows for parallel processing of spectral data without the need for multiple FFT UGens, and to copy out data at that point in the chain for other purposes. chainA and chainB must be the same size. The output will carry further chainA, so you chan insert the ugen at the appropriate place in the signal chain.

arg.name: chainA
arg.doc: the first FFT'ed buffer (this gets replaced by the output signal)

arg.name: chainB
arg.doc: the second FFT'ed buffer

doc.text: A phase vocoder UGen that combines the magnitudes of first input and phases of the second input. phases of the first input.

arg.name: chain
arg.doc: the FFT'ed buffer

arg.name: shift
arg.doc: phase shift in radians

doc.text: A phase vocoder UGen that shifts the phase of each bins by a given amount.

arg.name: chain
arg.doc: the FFT'ed buffer

doc.text: A phase vocoder UGen that shift the phase of all bins by 90 degrees.

arg.name: chain
arg.doc: the FFT'ed buffer

doc.text: A phase vocoder UGen that shift the phase of all bins by 270 (or -90) degrees.

arg.name: chainA
arg.doc: the first FFT'ed buffer (this gets replaced by the output signal)

arg.name: chainB
arg.doc: the second FFT'ed buffer

doc.text: A phase vocoder UGen that outputs the bins with the minimum magnitude of the two inputs.

arg.name: chainA
arg.doc: the first FFT'ed buffer (this gets replaced by the output signal)

arg.name: chainB
arg.doc: the second FFT'ed buffer

doc.text: A phase vocoder UGen that outputs the bins with the maximum magnitude of the two inputs.

arg.name: chainA
arg.doc: the first FFT'ed buffer (this gets replaced by the output signal)

arg.name: chainB
arg.doc: the second FFT'ed buffer

doc.text: A phase vocoder UGen that performs a complex multiplication of the two inputs. The formula is `(Re(A) * Re(B) - Im(A) * Im(B)) + i(Im(A) * Re(B) + Re(A) * Im(B))`.

arg.name: chainA
arg.doc: the first FFT'ed buffer (this gets replaced by the output signal)

arg.name: chainB
arg.doc: the second FFT'ed buffer

doc.text: A phase vocoder UGen that performs a complex division of the two inputs. Be careful that `chainB`, the divisor, does not contain zeroes as they would obviously blow up the division.

arg.name: chainA
arg.doc: the first FFT'ed buffer (this gets replaced by the output signal)

arg.name: chainB
arg.doc: the second FFT'ed buffer

doc.text: A phase vocoder UGen that performs a complex addition of the two inputs. The formula is `(Re(A) + Re(B)) + i(Im(A) + Im(B))`.

arg.name: chain
arg.doc: the FFT'ed buffer

arg.name: numTeeth
arg.doc: the number of periods in the rectangle wave, where zero would mean the input signal is not affected, one means that there is exactly one period of the wave across the spectrum, hence one pass-band and one stop-band.

arg.name: phase
arg.doc: the phase offset of the rectangle wave, where 1.0 is one full period. This is like the offset into the wavetable holding the rectangle, so a value of 0.25 means we start 25% into the basic waveform, and after 0.75 periods the next full period (high slope) begins.

arg.name: width
arg.doc: the pulse width between 0.0 (infinitely small high slope, so all bins filtered out) to 0.5 (half period is high slope, half period is low slope) to 1.0 (maximally wide high slope, no bins filtered out).

doc.text: A phase vocoder UGen that makes a series of gaps in a spectrum. This is done by multiplying the spectrum with a kind of rectangle wave that goes from zero to nyquist. The high slope of the rectangle lets the input bins pass (quasi pass-band), the low slope filteres them out (quasi stop-band).

arg.name: chainA
arg.doc: the first FFT'ed buffer (this gets replaced by the output signal)

arg.name: chainB
arg.doc: the second FFT'ed buffer

arg.name: numTeeth
arg.doc: the number of periods in the rectangle wave, where zero would mean the first input signal is fully passed through, one means that there is exactly one period of the wave across the spectrum, hence one pass-band (first signal passed through) and one stop-band (second signal passed through).

arg.name: phase
arg.doc: the phase offset of the rectangle wave, where 1.0 is one full period. This is like the offset into the wavetable holding the rectangle, so a value of 0.25 means we start 25% into the basic waveform, and after 0.75 periods the next full period (high slope) begins.

arg.name: width
arg.doc: the pulse width between 0.0 (infinitely small high slope, so all bins are copied from the second input) to 0.5 (half period is high slope -- copied from first input --, half period is low slope -- copied from second input) to 1.0 (maximally wide high slope, so all bins passed from the first input).

doc.text: A phase vocoder UGen that switches between two input spectra according to a rectangle wave. This is basically identical to `PV_RectComb`, however during the low slopes of the rectangle wavewave, instead of clearing out the bins, it copies over the corresponding bins of the second fft input buffer.

arg.name: chain
arg.doc: the FFT'ed buffer

arg.name: wipe
arg.doc: can range between -1 and +1. if wipe == 0 then there is no effect. if wipe > 0 then it acts like a high pass filter, clearing bins from the bottom up. if wipe < 0 then it acts like a low pass filter, clearing bins from the top down.

doc.text: A phase vocoder UGen that clears bins above or below a cutoff point.

arg.name: chainA
arg.doc: the first FFT'ed buffer (this gets replaced by the output signal)

arg.name: chainB
arg.doc: the second FFT'ed buffer

arg.name: wipe
arg.doc: can range between -1 and +1. if wipe == 0 then the output is the same as inA. if wipe > 0 then it begins replacing with bins from inB from the bottom up. if wipe < 0 then it begins replacing with bins from inB from the top down.

doc.text: A phase vocoder UGen that combine low and high bins from two inputs. It does so by copiying low bins from one input and the high bins of the other, thus realizes a kind of "wipe" between the two input signals.

arg.name: chain
arg.doc: the FFT'ed buffer

arg.name: thresh
arg.doc: magnitude threshold used for general filtering, prior to the local-maximum-filtering

doc.text: A phase vocoder UGen that passes only those bins whose magnitudes constitute local maxima. Additionally, the given threshold is also used to filter out bins whose magnitude lies below this threshold.

arg.name: chain
arg.doc: the FFT'ed buffer

doc.text: A phase vocoder UGen that converts the bins into their complex conjugate counterparts. The complex conjugate is equal to the input, but with reversed sign of the imaginary part.

arg.name: chain
arg.doc: the FFT'ed buffer

arg.name: wipe
arg.doc: the amount of bins scrambled, from 0 (none) to 1 (all bins scrambled).

arg.name: width
arg.doc: a value from zero to one, indicating the maximum randomized distance of a bin from its original location in the spectrum.

arg.name: trig
arg.doc: causes a new random bin re-ordering to be made. a trigger occurs when passing from non-positive to positive value.

doc.text: A phase vocoder UGen that randomizes the order of the bins. The trigger will select a new random ordering.

arg.name: chain
arg.doc: the FFT'ed buffer

arg.name: bins
arg.doc: number of bins to average on each side of bin. As this number rises, so will CPU usage.

doc.text: A phase vocoder UGen that averages each bin's magnitude with its neighbors.

arg.name: chain
arg.doc: the FFT'ed buffer

arg.name: stretch
arg.doc: the factor to multiply each bin position with

arg.name: shift
arg.doc: the translation of the spectrum, in number of bins

doc.text: A phase vocoder UGen that stretches and shifts the magnitudes of the spectrum. This is live `PV_BinShift` but instead of scaling and shifting the whole complex bins (magnitude and phase), this only operates on the magnitudes and leaves the phases in their original bins.

arg.name: chain
arg.doc: the FFT'ed buffer

arg.name: stretch
arg.doc: the factor to multiply each bin position with, where 0.5 kind of transposes the signal down by an octave, and 2 transposes it up by an octave.

arg.name: shift
arg.doc: the translation of the spectrum, in number of bins. Since the FFT produces a linear frequency axis, the will produce harmonic distortion.

doc.text: A phase vocoder UGen that stretches and shifts the spectrum. It takes each bin, first stretches (scales) its position (bin number) with a given factor, and then adds a shift to it.

arg.name: chainA
arg.doc: the first FFT'ed buffer (this gets replaced by the output signal)

arg.name: chainB
arg.doc: the second FFT'ed buffer

arg.name: wipe
arg.doc: the crossfader position from 0.0 (all bins are taken from `chainA`) to 1.0 (all bins are taken from `chainB`). For instance, if wipe is 0.5, half of the bins are taken from either input. The decision whether a bin is taken from A or B is random, however remains constant between two triggers.

arg.name: trig
arg.doc: a signal the triggers the re-newed process of determining for each bin whether it will be taken from input A or B. A trigger occurs when passing from non-positive to positive value.

doc.text: A phase vocoder UGen that crossfades between two input spectra by taking bins randomly from them according to a given probability.

arg.name: chain
arg.doc: the FFT'ed buffer

arg.name: trig
arg.doc: to trigger a new selection of random phases. A trigger occurs when passing from non-positive to positive value.

doc.text: A phase vocoder UGen that adds a different constant random phase shift to each bin. The trigger will select a new set of random phases.

arg.name: chain
arg.doc: the FFT'ed buffer

arg.name: wipe
arg.doc: the probability (from 0 to 1) of bins being wiped out, hence 0 means no bins are wiped out, 1 means all bins are wiped out (output will be silence).

arg.name: trig
arg.doc: causes a new random bin selection to be made. a trigger occurs when passing from non-positive to positive value.

doc.text: A phase vocoder UGen that randomly clears out bins of the signal. Which bins are wiped out is subject to a random choice (only the amount is specified) that remains constant between triggers.

arg.name: chain
arg.doc: the FFT'ed buffer

arg.name: freeze
arg.doc: whether the current levels are frozen (> 0) or not (0).

doc.text: A phase vocoder UGen that freezes the magnitudes at current levels. Freezing happens when the freeze input has a value of > 0.

arg.name: in
arg.doc: the realtime input to be convolved

arg.name: kernel
arg.doc: buffer identifier for the fixed kernel, which may be modulated in combination with the trigger

arg.name: trig
arg.doc: updates the kernel on a change from non-positive to positive (<= 0 to >0)

arg.name: frameSize
arg.doc: size of the kernel. this must be a power of two. the FFT calculated internally by the UGen has a size of twice this value. The maximum allowed frameSize is 65536(?).

doc.text: A frequency-domain convolution UGen using a fixed kernel which can be updated by a trigger signal. The delay caused by the convolution when the kernel is a dirac impulse is equal to `frameSize - (controlBlockSize + 1)` (measured august 2010), so for a frameSize of 2048 and a controlBlockSize of 64, this is 1983 sample frames.

arg.name: in
arg.doc: the realtime input to be convolved

arg.name: kernelL
arg.doc: buffer identifier for the left channel's fixed kernel, which may be modulated in combination with the trigger

arg.name: kernelR
arg.doc: buffer identifier for the right channel's fixed kernel, which may be modulated in combination with the trigger

arg.name: trig
arg.doc: updates the kernel on a change from non-positive to positive (<= 0 to >0), and starts a new crossfade from the previous kernel to the new one over the given amount of periods.

arg.name: frameSize
arg.doc: size of each kernel. this must be a power of two. the FFT calculated internally by the UGen has a size of twice this value. The maximum allowed frameSize is 65536(?).

arg.name: fadePeriods
arg.doc: The number of periods over which a crossfade is performed. This must be an integer

doc.text: A frequency domain stereo convolution UGen, capable of performing linear crossfades between kernel updates. When receiving a trigger, there is a linear crossfade between the old kernel the new buffer contents. It operates similar to Convolution2L, however uses two buffers and outputs a stereo signal, resulting in better CPU usage than two discrete instances of Convolution2L as this way one FFT transformation per period is saved.
A UGen for triggered convolution in the time domain.

arg.name: in
arg.doc: the input signal to sum up

arg.name: length
arg.doc: the length of the sliding window over the input signal. these are the number of audio sample-frames for audio-rate calculation, or the number of blocks for control-rate calculation summed up.

doc.text: A UGen calculating the running sum of an input signal over a given number of samples.

arg.name: in
arg.doc: the signal to smooth out

arg.name: dur
arg.doc: the ramp-time (seconds) which is also the interval of the sampling

doc.text: A UGen which produces a linear lag (time smear) regarding and input signal. Other than `Lag` which is a feedback filter with exponential decay, `Ramp` applies a linear ramp. This is achieved by sampling the input signal at regular intervals given by the `lagTime` and starting a new line segment after each interval.

arg.name: in
arg.doc: input signal.

arg.name: time
arg.doc: 60 dB lag time in seconds.

doc.text: An exponential lag UGen. This is essentially the same as `OnePole` except that instead of supplying the coefficient directly, it is calculated from a 60 dB lag time. This is the time required for the filter to converge to within 0.01 % of a value. This is useful for smoothing out control signals.

arg.name: in
arg.doc: input signal.

arg.name: time
arg.doc: 60 dB lag time in seconds.

doc.text: A cascaded exponential lag UGen. `Lag2.kr(in, time)` is equivalent to `Lag.kr(Lag.kr(in, time), time)`, thus resulting in a smoother transition. This saves on CPU as you only have to calculate the decay factor once instead of twice.

arg.name: in
arg.doc: input signal.

arg.name: time
arg.doc: 60 dB lag time in seconds.

doc.text: A cascaded exponential lag UGen. `Lag3.kr(in, time)` is equivalent to `Lag.kr(Lag.kr(Lag.kr(Lag.kr(in, time), time), time)`, thus resulting in a smoother transition. This saves on CPU as you only have to calculate the decay factor once instead of three times.

arg.name: in
arg.doc: input signal.

arg.name: timeUp
arg.doc: 60 dB lag time in seconds effective during a rising slope in the input signal

arg.name: timeDown
arg.doc: 60 dB lag time in seconds effective during a falling slope in the input signal

doc.text: An exponential lag UGen with separate inputs for up and down slope. This is essentially the same as `Lag` except that you can supply a different 60 dB time for when the signal goes up, from when the signal goes down.

arg.name: in
arg.doc: input signal.

arg.name: timeUp
arg.doc: 60 dB lag time in seconds effective during a rising slope in the input signal

arg.name: timeDown
arg.doc: 60 dB lag time in seconds effective during a falling slope in the input signal

doc.text: A cascaded exponential lag UGen with separate inputs for up and down slope. `Lag2UD.kr(in, up, down)` is equivalent to `LagUD.kr(LagUD.kr(in, up, down), up, down)`, thus resulting in a smoother transition. This saves on CPU as you only have to calculate the decay factors once instead of twice.

arg.name: in
arg.doc: input signal.

arg.name: timeUp
arg.doc: 60 dB lag time in seconds effective during a rising slope in the input signal

arg.name: timeDown
arg.doc: 60 dB lag time in seconds effective during a falling slope in the input signal

doc.text: A cascaded exponential lag UGen with separate inputs for up and down slope. `Lag3UD.kr(in, up, down)` is equivalent to `LagUD.kr(LagUD.kr(LagUD.kr(in, up, down), up, down), up, down)`, thus resulting in a smoother transition. This saves on CPU as you only have to calculate the decay factors once instead of three times.

arg.name: in
arg.doc: input signal to be processed

arg.name: coeff
arg.doc: feedback coefficient. Should be between -1 and +1

arg.name: in
arg.doc: input signal to be processed

arg.name: coeff
arg.doc: feed forward coefficient. +0.5 makes a two point averaging filter (see also `LPZ1`), -0.5 makes a differentiator (see also `HPZ1`), +1 makes a single sample delay (see also `Delay1`), -1 makes an inverted single sample delay.

arg.name: in
arg.doc: input signal to be processed

arg.name: in
arg.doc: input signal to be processed

arg.name: in
arg.doc: input signal to be processed

doc.text:
An integrator UGen with exponential decay of past values. This is essentially the same as `Integrator` except that instead of supplying the coefficient directly, it is calculated from a 60 dB decay time. This is the time required for the integrator to lose 99.9 % of its value or -60dB.
Note: This should not be confused with `Lag` which does not overshoot due to integration, but asymptotically follows the input signal.

arg.name: in
arg.doc: input signal to be processed

arg.name: in
arg.doc: input signal to be processed

arg.name: coeff
arg.doc: the leak coefficient. Should be between -1 and +1

arg.name: in
arg.doc: input signal to be processed

arg.name: in
arg.doc: input signal to be processed

arg.name: in
arg.doc: input signal

arg.name: up
arg.doc: maximum upward slope.

arg.name: down
arg.doc: maximum downward slope.

doc.text: A slew rate limiter UGen. Limits the slope of an input signal. The slope is expressed in units per second.

arg.name: in
arg.doc: input signal to be measured

arg.name: in
arg.doc: The signal to be compressed / expanded / gated.

arg.name: ctrl
arg.doc: The signal whose amplitude controls the processor. Often the same as in, but one may wish to apply equalization or delay to it to change the compressor character (side-chaining), or even feed a completely different signal, for instance in a ducking application.

arg.name: thresh
arg.doc: Control signal amplitude threshold, which determines the break point between slopeBelow and slopeAbove. Usually 0..1. The control signal amplitude is calculated using RMS.

arg.name: ratioBelow
arg.doc: Slope of the amplitude curve below the threshold. If this slope > 1.0, the amplitude will drop off more quickly the softer the control signal gets; when the control signal is close to 0 amplitude, the output should be exactly zero -- hence, noise gating. Values < 1.0 are possible, but it means that a very low-level control signal will cause the input signal to be amplified, which would raise the noise floor.

arg.name: ratioAbove
arg.doc: Slope of the amplitude curve above the threshold. Values < 1.0 achieve compression (louder signals are attenuated); > 1.0, you get expansion (louder signals are made even louder). For 3:1 compression, you would use a value of 1/3 here.

arg.name: attack
arg.doc: The amount of time it takes for the amplitude adjustment to kick in fully. This is usually pretty small, not much more than 10 milliseconds (the default value). I often set it as low as 2 milliseconds (0.002).

arg.name: release
arg.doc: The amount of time for the amplitude adjustment to be released. Usually a bit longer than attack; if both times are too short, you can get some (possibly unwanted) artifacts.

doc.text: A compressor, expander, limiter, gate and ducking UGen. This dynamic processor uses a hard-knee characteristic. All of the thresholds and ratios are given as direct values, not in decibels!

arg.name: in
arg.doc: input signal to be processed.

arg.name: freq
arg.doc: cutoff frequency.

arg.name: rq
arg.doc: the reciprocal of Q, hence bandwidth / cutoffFreq.

doc.text:
A 2nd order (12db per oct rolloff) resonant low pass filter UGen. The B equalization suite is based on the Second Order Section (SOS) biquad UGen.
Note: Biquad coefficient calculations imply certain amount of CPU overhead. These plugin UGens contain optimizations such that the coefficients get updated only when there has been a change to one of the filter's parameters. This can cause spikes in CPU performance and should be considered when using several of these units.

arg.name: in
arg.doc: input signal to be processed.

arg.name: freq
arg.doc: cutoff frequency.

arg.name: rq
arg.doc: the reciprocal of Q, hence bandwidth / cutoffFreq.

arg.name: in

arg.name: freq

arg.name: freq

arg.name: rq

An all pass filter UGen. The B equalization suite is based on the Second Order Section (SOS) biquad UGen.

This can cause spikes in CPU performance and should be considered when using several of these units.

arg.name: in
arg.doc: input signal to be processed.

arg.name: freq
arg.doc: cutoff frequency.

arg.name: rs
arg.doc: the reciprocal of the slope S (Shell boost/cut slope). When `S = 1`, the shelf slope is as steep as it can be and remain monotonically increasing or decreasing gain with frequency. The shelf slope, in dB/octave, remains proportional to S for all other values for a fixed freq/sample-rate and `gain`.

arg.name: gain
arg.doc: boost/cut at the cutoff frequency (in decibels).

Note: Biquad coefficient calculations imply certain amount of CPU overhead. These plugin UGens contain optimizations such that the coefficients get updated only when there has been a change to one of the filter's parameters. This can cause spikes in CPU performance and should be considered when using several of these units.

arg.name: in
